story:
Vision

There’s something very unfortunate about the message we send children of color when they don’t see themselves in books.  After all, books, especially children’s books transmit values. That’s why I wrote MY SKIN HAS POLKA DOTS.  It is a board book featuring a boy with brown skin and multi-colored spots.  The pages are full of bold colors and whimsical illustrations that will add a new perspective to the conversation about skin color and encourage children ages 0-5 years old to never question the brilliance of their differences.  Delivered in a playful, child-centered tone, it reminds us of the connection between appearance and ancestry, and is a fun rhyming message that parents and children will love to read again and again.

 

A book about skin:

So why does a book about skin color matter?  Well, this book was inspired by the journey of a friend’s son. When I found out that he was asking how the brown could actually be washed off, I allowed myself to be sad for a moment (because um, tear!) and then was committed to a solution in the form of this book.  The concept that his skin color was given to him by his grandparents and all of his ancestors excited him. It excited me too! So often, beauty is explained by comparison. So rather than saying brown is pretty because it's the same color as say, a chestnut horse (weird right? But those are lyrics from a song on a popular children's show!), we can find new and interesting ways to have conversations with children all of shades and with any kind of spots. I see books as a powerful tool in reinforcing values; reflecting back to children how they are special and matter to this world. I humbly think this book can help parents have meaningful conversations even with their little ones. My 16-month old loves this text (he hasn’t even seen the illustrations yet!), and I hope it can bring a similar level of humor and meaning to your family too.

 

About Me:

Hi, I’m Jenile. I live in Los Angeles with my husband and 17-month old son, and I want to tell stories that can inspire, amuse, and teach your children.  Writing a children’s book has been a natural progression for me that combines my intentional approach to motherhood with my background as a television writer and producer, having gotten my start at Nickelodeon over a decade ago. I had always dreamed of writing for children one day, but after becoming a mother, and struggling to find board and picture books for my son with diverse characters that could awaken things like compassion for others, reinforce academics, or just tickle the funny bone -- “one day” turned into right now.

 

The Impact

My plan to self-publish is a deliberate attempt to have a direct conversation with the recipients of this book - parents and supporters just like you who can use it to spark conversations in your families and circles of influence. It’s hard to find books with diverse characters; made for diverse audiences. It’s even harder to find them in board book form to reach infants and toddlers!  If you join this campaign, not only are you helping to share a fun and empowering message with young children, you’re also helping add to the growing collection of board books for early readers of color.

 

Costs of Campaign and Plan for Funding

With the funding I raise from this campaign, my plan is simple. I want this book published! It’s why I have simplified the level of sponsorship to accommodate a bulk order of 500 books, the cost of shipping and receiving an ISBN/Barcode.

 

Levels of sponsorship:

$10 - e-book with bold and colorful illustrations & a special thanks mention at the end of the book!

$30 - physical board book, signed and with a dedication to the recipient (yay!) & a special thanks mention at the end of the book!

$100.00 physical board book, signed and with a dedication to the recipient (yay!) a special thanks mention at the end of the book, and a customized illustration featuring any child in your life surrounded by people in their family tree. You submit photos; I will turn those photos into a custom illustration and print on canvas with an excerpt from the book that says "I love my family so I'm proud of everything that's me." and deliver directly to you. This makes a great gift!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to financial pledges, I would love if you could forward this link to even just one mother of a toddler (or father, or auntie, or caregiver...) with whom you think this message would resonate.  Thanks so much to my family and friends for supporting this creative dream, and to all of you for the consideration!

story:
Reflecting on how quickly technologies change our lives, I tried to imagine what our world would be in the near future. So the idea of the book was born, and I did not notice how it was written.

This is the story of a musician who cannot come to terms with the new order of the world in which technology is increasingly taking space from people.

Who is this book for?

If you also, like me, often think about the future of the world, you will like it.

If you are young and think what profession to choose, the book will be useful.

If you like music, in particular rock, then, most likely, after reading you will recommend the book to your friends.

I wrote the book in Russian, I think on it. I would like to publish it on Amazon, but Amazon does not publish books in Russian. Therefore, I am here.

Who knows, perhaps thanks to this campaign for Indigo, the world will read the book and change a little for the better.

This is the first book I wrote, but I still have a lot of ideas. I hope that these ideas will also turn into good interesting books.

Now professionals should work on my manuscript so that I would not be ashamed of reviews on Amazon. I need a literary translation into English, I need the services of an editor, and I also need to prepare a good cover.

Anyone who can help me hold these events, has a unique opportunity to be one of the first to receive a new warning novel, which, perhaps, sometime will be filmed.

Given that the book consists of 29,000 words, the budget for these expenses is as follows:

• Literary translation - $ 4500

• Developmental Editing - $ 1300

• Copyediting - $ 350

• Cover Design - $ 450

Risks & Challenges

The main risk in this project is the risk of copyright infringement of this book, or its translation. In addition, there is the risk of poor translation and editing. To avoid this, I plan to place an order for all the above services only in those organizations that are recommended by Amazon on this page: https://kdp.amazon.com/en_US/help/topic/G201723120

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to participating in the creation of the book in cash, I very much ask you to spread the message about this campaign on your pages on social networks or using instant messengers. The more people learn about the project, the greater the chance of success.

Thank you in advance!

(Unless otherwise specified, perks listed refer to "Little Boy Lost," or "LBL.")

About Mannison Press

Mannison Press, LLC, was co-founded in April of 2019 by indie authors Deidre J Owen (FL) and Ronald Linson (NY).  Between Owen's illustration, design, and self-publishing experience and Linson's literary prowess and top notch editing skills, the two create a well-rounded publishing team. The plucky little indie publisher hit the ground running, and by the end of last year had published a full multi-author anthology and nine Mannison Minibooks, with plans in place for several more Minibooks, two full-length collections, and a companion volume for the anthology.

However, starting up a small business can be rather costly. Even with a growing catalogue of publications, the financing of larger endeavors -- like another anthology -- can still be quite a challenge. 

But that's where you can help.

What We Need & What You Get

Crowdfunding for our previous anthology, "Little Girl Lost," provided just enough for us to meet our three primary objectives: pay our contributing authors, offset production costs, and fulfill the perks offered by the campaign. Our goal for this new companion volume has been set at $1,500 which will help cover the following expenses:

  • Paying our authors. The first anthology was capped at 13 authors; this one, however, is being left open for consideration. We anticipate between 12 and 15. Contracted authors are offered a payment of $0.02 per word and a copy of the book itself. This is very attainable if the campaign is successful! Of the funds we raise, 80% will be allocated to paying our authors.
  • Fulfillment of perks. We would like to offer our biggest supporters something in return! While some of the perks cost nothing to fulfill (like ebooks and illustration packages), other perks include various bundling of our anthologies in print. The remaining 20% raised by this campaign will be used to fulfill these perks.
  • If we don't reach our goal, the entirety of funds collected will still go into the project! While some fundraising programs will refund all monies raised if the project goal isn't met, IndieGoGo only maintains a minimum requirement. As long as we reach this minimum, we will receive the funds. So, every little bit helps!

The Impact

So what happens if this anthology is a success? Just as was stated in the previous campaign: WE. DO. MORE. Simple as that. Ideas are already flowing for future anthologies.

This project will also help boost visibility as the company continues to develop other areas of publishing. For example, we look forward to further expanding our line of "Mannison Minibooks." These are a non-serial line of short stories in print...miniature books to be read in a single sitting. But don't let their pocket-size cuteness fool you! Some of these stories are heavy-hitting.

Risks & Challenges

Are there risks? For us, sure. We have put a lot of heart and soul, sweat and tears, dollars and cents into our fledgling company. However, if you choose to back our project here on IndieGoGo you can rest easy! Once the campaign reaches a minimum amount, the funds will be released to us and allocated as described above. And if it doesn't reach the minimum? No worries, friend...you will be refunded the full amount. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute this time, you can still help us out! (And if you've read this far that means you're at least intrigued. Admit it. This is cool.)

So make some noise! Share it on social media, mention it to your book club, tell your mom...help us get the word out. Help "Little Boy Lost" get FOUND.

story:
Join our Mission to Share the Power of Love, Acceptance & Connection!

Hi! I’m Laura Duksta, an award-winning children’s book author, inspirational speaker and ambassador of love. I have a new book in the works and we need your help to publish it! 

My new book, No Matter What, I Love You - You Are My Sister, You Are My Brother, illustrates how love transcends everything, no matter what the circumstance. It shares messages of unconditional love, kindness, and acceptance, encouraging children and adults alike to come together amid a world of uncertainty and divisiveness.

I'm a big believer that LOVE is the truth of who we are. Beyond politics, religion, race, nationality and finances, LOVE elevates and unites all of us! Now more than ever, we want our children to know how truly loved they are no matter what is going on in their lives or in the world around them.

I want you to know this, too—and this powerful message helps to accomplish this and more. But we need your support to share this timely and timeless book with children across the world!

 

One of Laura Duksta's many school visits, focusing on LOVE, which diminishes bullying

 

Why Now and Why This Book

We have all felt the fear, divisiveness, stress, trauma and tragedy of 2020, with people praying that this year just hurries up and comes to an end. The problem with this, is that we have a false sense, that at the stroke of midnight, on December 31st, everything is somehow going to be different... the truth is, nothing is going to change unless we do! It’s up to US to CHOOSE LOVE!

As Albert Einstein shared, "No problem can be solved from the same level of consciousness that created it.”  That's what we're aiming to do with this book—help parents, children, teachers and leaders tune in to the higher frequency of LOVE—the only thing that can truly erase the fear that is plaguing too many of our hearts and minds. Together, let's declare 2021 The Year of Love! 

Take action by supporting this campaign, reading this book with your loved ones, and sharing it with your communities and classrooms. The choice is ours: LOVE or FEAR! Fear has us caught up in the stress and struggle of politics, unrest and the global pandemic, but in LOVE’S presence, fear dissolves and we can begin to heal and transform, on an individual, familial, national and global level.

Let 2021's headline read…. Goodbye Global Pandemic of Fear, Hello Global Phenomena of LOVE! 

Laura's Love Library, including New York Times bestseller I Love You More, I'll Hug You More and our newest soon to be book.... No Matter What I Love You -- You Are My Sister, You Are My Brother.  Scheduled to release on Global Love Day - May 1, 2021.

 

Why We Need Your Support & How We’ll Thank You

In part, I opted to take a crowdfunding approach for this book as it makes it a team effort. It's not just my book—it's OUR book! 

Together with your support, we can inspire children everywhere to embrace what makes them and others unique, while also tuning in to what unites us all...LOVE.

  • Why we need your help: We’re aiming to raise $33,333 to support upfront publishing costs, print at least 10,000 copies in Canada, cover some of the start up costs, including design, and release the book SPRING 2021. We launched Be the Light Media to get back to our grassroots efforts and independently publish the book.
  • Why we decided to self publish: While Trevor Romain (the book’s illustrator) and I have books with Top 10 publishing companies, we wanted the opportunity to work together and bring this unique book to the world now. Our joint intention is to help readers rise above differences, tune into the power of love and connection, and bring forth a brighter world for our children. 
  • What you’ll get as a token of our appreciation: Unique opportunities are available to donors and Ambassadors of Love like you! When you donate, you receive exclusive gifts and experiences, such as signed books, gift sets, virtual school programming and opportunities to be included within the actual book itself. Follow this project for BONUS GIFTS! 
    • Love Bugs & Ambassadors of Love -- YOU or your loved ones name or picture IN the book. *Must be secured by 12/13/20 -- this has been moved as our PUB date has!
    • Champions for Love -- Virtual school visits, first THREE will have both Laura and Trevor
    • One Love & Big Love -- unsigned and signed copies of the new book
    • Warriors for and Empire of Love -- donate books to a NICU or your favorite cause
    • Book's Release to coincide with Global Love Day May 1, 2021
  • If we don’t reach our entire goal: We will still use funds raised to publish as many copies of the book as possible.
  • New to Indiegogo: Click on the colored perk box to find out more about each reward, then you'll be able to choose if you want to claim it, and if YES, you'll be instructed to pay with your credit card. 

 

Trevor and the orphan at Botshabelo in South Africa who inspired this unique illustration style

 

More About the Book

Can a book change the world? Well, maybe not a book. But we know what can...LOVE!

No Matter What, I Love You - You Are My Sister, You Are My Brother affirms the presence of light, love, goodness and humanity within every child and adult. The book touches on topics children are confronted with on the news or in person, including race, nationality, faith, culture, wealth, success, politics and gender, empowering readers to embrace their unique attributes and share their inner light with everyone around them.

Best-selling author and illustrator Trevor Romain has created a series of heartfelt and moving illustrations for the book, inspired by photos and stories of children from around the world. For more than 30 years, the children’s champion and advocate has shared his motivational and unique self-love, healing, and empowering messages to millions.

In addition to developing programming for PBS about young people and the challenges they face, Romain has traveled the world with the USO to visit and inspire military children, as well as terminally ill children in hospitals worldwide. Romain has written more than 50 books and his works have been published in 22 different languages. 

 

One of Trevor Romain's many USO visits with children from around the world

 

More About Me

I am an Ambassador of Love, inspirational speaker and New York Times bestselling children's author. You may have read or heard about my first book, l Love You More, which has sold nearly a million copies in seven languages.

My works also include You are a Gift to the World/The World is a Gift to You and I'll Hug You More.

From a young age, I knew I was meant to travel the world, meet my brothers and sisters and share the message of love. My newest book will help me do just that! It is the heart of who I am, and who I believe we all truly are—LOVE! 

Through my work, I aim to generate conversations of love around the world by reaching as many hearts, homes and classrooms as possible with the power, magic, and message of love, appreciation, and connection.

I believe that when people know they are loved, anything is possible. I lost all my hair to a condition called Alopecia Areata at the age of eleven. It took me many years to learn to love myself and allow others to love me. Along my own personal journey to love, I developed a deep sense of understanding, compassion and love for humanity. I am now fulfilling my mission of generating the conversation of love around the world  through my books, school programs and speaking engagements.

I’ve delivered my inspirational program, "Empowering YOU to Shine!", to 100,000+ students and educators across the country. I've also presented as the keynote speaker for a diverse array of groups and organizations, including Women of Energy in Jamaica and Delta Airlines.

My work has been featured in dozens of blogs, magazines, newspapers, radio programs and TV shows, including USA Today, the Miami Herald, the Sun-Sentinel and Boca Magazine. I was featured on air with Whoopi Goldberg and Sally Jesse Raphael, and on several local TV programs, including South Florida Today.

Some of the biggest hearts in the publishing and human potential worlds endorse my books and programs, including Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen (co-authors of the Chicken Soup for the Soul series) and the beloved Dr. Wayne Dyer.

I’m a part of the Wise Mind Project, a South Florida-based non-profit bringing mindfulness, resiliency and inner wisdom training to educators, middle school students and their families. I’m an avid student and teacher of human potential and transformational work. I’m a cofounder of CoCreating Our Reality, which has amassed more than 13,000 members worldwide - and was (almost) featured on Oprah! A video clip of our project was put together, but cut from a taped show that ran long! I’ve served on the board for the Boys and Girls Club of Broward County, spoken and mentored for the Children’s Alopecia Project, partnered with Plant Trees 4 Life, as well as having donated hundreds of books to NICU families, causes, relief work, and orphanages around the nation and world. 

Laura visits with the Children's Alopecia Project at Barnes & Noble at The Grove, Los Angeles

 

Join Our Campaign for Love

We appreciate any level of financial support you can give,  and we’d be so grateful if you could help get the word out about our "Campaign for Love" on social media and in your circles!

  • Simply copy and paste this page’s URL on your social channels
  • It helps tremendously to share the campaign in groups you belong to, or even directly with loved ones, friends and teachers 
  • Or, use Indiegogo’s sharing tools to help us build awareness and excitement for this special initiative
  • If you have further questions, thoughts, ideas, please share them here or send via my social or website -- we will be checking/answering daily! 

 

With your help and love, anything is possible! Thank YOU again for your support!

Keep Shining!

Laura Duksta

story:
Gliding Barnacles

Num ano em que celebrar o Gliding Barnacles como o conhecemos é impossível, procuramos novas formas de o manter vivo.

Por essa razão, decidimos imprimir e publicar o livro “PERCEBES” - da autoria de Valter Vinagre - que nos presenteia com a sua visão das ultimas 3 edições do GB e perpetua, em papel, as memórias felizes dos últimos anos. 

Pedimos então a ajuda de todos para concretizar este nosso plano editorial. Todas as contribuições, por mais pequenas que sejam, serão recompensadas com uma série de incentivos. Entre eles: brindes oficiais do GB, peças exclusivas impressas em serigrafia, o livro "PERCEBES", a publicação “We're On The Road to Somewhere” ou até pranchas feitas pelos shapers Diogo Appleton, Nico (Wavegliders), Manel (Livestoked) e Robin Kegel. 

Mais informações no feed da campanha.

 

Livro PERCEBES, de Valter Vinagre

“O fotógrafo Valter Vinagre, o surfista Michael Lay, o chef Diogo Rocha, o vigneron João Roseira, o ilustrador João Catarino, o shaper Thomas Bexon, o músico Victor Torpedo, o pintor Francisco Vidal, o designer Pedro Falcão, estão entre os que habitualmente vêm terminar o verão, entre os dias na praia do cabedelo e as noites numa velha garagem no centro da Figueira da Foz. Um encontro de autores, aberto a todos, dentro e fora do surf, para celebrar o mar. Sardinhada e serigrafia, sofá na praia com piano, um copo de vinho depois do surf, o som dos Filhos do Tédio enquanto alguém apara a barba ou termina uma prancha. Mais produção do que exposição. Muita areia e sal numa festa de garagem com um grupo de amigos que partilham o Atlântico nesta frente ocidental da Europa. Mais do que a prática do surf celebra-se o lugar, o mar, a rebentação, o momento.

O festival Gliding Barnacles segue a receita duma caldeirada tradicional, com todos os ingredientes colocados no mesmo tacho de uma só vez, ao contrário dos campeonatos de surf onde o público fica em terra a admirar os surfistas. Aqui todos são convidados a partilhar o mar. O Valter Vinagre aceitou mergulhar connosco no tacho. Acrescentou luz ao surf da manhã e à noite iluminada. Fixou-a sobretudo nas pessoas, entre o espanto dos que o acaso trouxe e a celebração do reencontro dos que sabem ao que vêm.”

 

----

 

Gliding Barnacles

In a year when celebrating Gliding Barnacles as we used to know it is impossible, we look for new ways to keep it alive.

For this reason, we decided to print and publish the book "BARNACLES” - by Valter Vinagre - which gives us with the author’s vision of the last 3 editions of GB and perpetuates in paper the happy memories of these past years. 

Therefore, we’re asking for everyone's help to realize this editorial plan of ours. All contributions, no matter how small, will be rewarded with a series of incentives. Among them: official GB gifts, exclusive pieces printed in serigraphy, the book "BARNACLES", the publication "We're On The Road to Somewhere" or even surfboards made by the shapers Diogo Appleton, Nico (Wavegliders), Manel (Livestoked) and Robin Kegel. 

For more information check the campaign feed.

 

PERCEBES - photography book, by Valter Vinagre

"The photographer Valter Vinagre, the surfer Michael Lay, the chef Diogo Rocha, the vigneron João Roseira, the illustrator João Catarino, the shaper Mitch Surman, the musician Victor Torpedo, the painter Francisco Vidal, the designer Pedro Falcão, are among those who usually come to finish the summer, between the days on the beach and the nights in an old garage in the center of Figueira da Foz. A meeting of authors, open to all, inside and outside the surf, to celebrate the sea. Sardine and serigraphy, sofa on the beach with piano, a glass of wine after the surf, the sound of the Sons of Boredom while someone trims the beard or finishes a board. More production than exhibition. Lots of sand and salt at a garage party with a group of friends who share the Atlantic on this western front of Europe. More than surfing, we celebrate the place, the sea, the break, the moment.

The Gliding Barnacles festival follows the recipe of a traditional stew, with all the ingredients placed in the same pot at once, unlike the surf championships where the public stands on land admiring the surfers. Here everyone is invited to share the sea. Valter Vinagre agreed to dive with us in the pot. He added light to the morning and night surfing. He fixed it mainly on the people, between the amazement of those who brought chance and the celebration of the reunion of those who know what they are coming to".

“O fotógrafo Valter Vinagre, o surfista Michael Lay, o chef Diogo Rocha, o vigneron João Roseira, o ilustrador João Catarino, o shaper Thomas Bexon, o músico Victor Torpedo, o pintor Francisco Vidal, o designer Pedro Falcão, estão entre os que habitualmente vêm terminar o verão, entre os dias na praia do cabedelo e as noites numa velha garagem no centro da Figueira da Foz. Um encontro de autores, aberto a todos, dentro e fora do surf, para celebrar o mar. Sardinhada e serigrafia, sofá na praia com piano, um copo de vinho depois do surf, o som dos Filhos do Tédio enquanto alguém apara a barba ou termina uma prancha. Mais produção do que exposição. Muita areia e sal numa festa de garagem com um grupo de amigos que partilham o Atlântico nesta frente ocidental da Europa. Mais do que a prática do surf celebra-se o lugar, o mar, a rebentação, o momento.
O festival Gliding Barnacles segue a receita duma caldeirada tradicional, com todos os ingredientes colocados no mesmo tacho de uma só vez, ao contrário dos campeonatos de surf onde o público fica em terra a admirar os surfistas. Aqui todos são convidados a partilhar o mar. O Valter Vinagre aceitou mergulhar connosco no tacho. Acrescentou luz ao surf da manhã e à noite iluminada. Fixou-a sobretudo nas pessoas, entre o espanto dos que o acaso trouxe e a celebração do reencontro dos que sabem ao que vêm.”
 
----
 
Gliding Barnacles
In a year when celebrating Gliding Barnacles as we used to know it is impossible, we look for new ways to keep it alive.
For this reason, we decided to print and publish the book "BARNACLES” - by Valter Vinagre - which gives us with the author’s vision of the last 3 editions of GB and perpetuates in paper the happy memories of these past years. 
Therefore, we’re asking for everyone's help to realize this editorial plan of ours. All contributions, no matter how small, will be rewarded with a series of incentives. Among them: official GB gifts, exclusive pieces printed in serigraphy, the book "BARNACLES", the publication "We're On The Road to Somewhere" or even surfboards made by the shapers Diogo Appleton, Nico (Wavegliders), Manel (Livestoked) and Robin Kegel. 
For more information check the campaign feed.
 
PERCEBES - photography book, by Valter Vinagre
"The photographer Valter Vinagre, the surfer Michael Lay, the chef Diogo Rocha, the vigneron João Roseira, the illustrator João Catarino, the shaper Mitch Surman, the musician Victor Torpedo, the painter Francisco Vidal, the designer Pedro Falcão, are among those who usually come to finish the summer, between the days on the beach and the nights in an old garage in the center of Figueira da Foz. A meeting of authors, open to all, inside and outside the surf, to celebrate the sea. Sardine and serigraphy, sofa on the beach with piano, a glass of wine after the surf, the sound of the Sons of Boredom while someone trims the beard or finishes a board. More production than exhibition. Lots of sand and salt at a garage party with a group of friends who share the Atlantic on this western front of Europe. More than surfing, we celebrate the place, the sea, the break, the moment.
The Gliding Barnacles festival follows the recipe of a traditional stew, with all the ingredients placed in the same pot at once, unlike the surf championships where the public stands on land admiring the surfers. Here everyone is invited to share the sea. Valter Vinagre agreed to dive with us in the pot. He added light to the morning and night surfing. He fixed it mainly on the people, between the amazement of those who brought chance and the celebration of the reunion of those who know what they are coming to".

story:
Overview

Poems are moments of revelation and story-telling that at their best illuminate life, choices and bring experiences of joy, beauty and recognition. CLOUDBREAK is a book of poetry about the arc of Heather's career in social justice and reproductive health-- what brought her there and how she transitioned through to a second career in art and writing. The book itself will be a softcover paperback about 100 pages in length. She would like to acknowledge the editors of the following publications in which some of these poems (or earlier versions of them) originally appeared or are about to be published: the Journal Sisyphus; Fog and Light-- San Francisco Poems through the Eyes of the Poets Who Live Here  Edited by Diane Frank; Swimming in Deep Blue, The Sky Away from Here, Bach In The Afternoon; Vistas & Byways, a Journal published through San Francisco State; Pandemic Puzzle Poems- An Anthology; and Journal Brine.

 

Poetic Matrix Press:

Poetic Matrix Press will publish CLOUDBREAK. This press has published in excess of 40 writers over many years including the works of Francisco X Alarcon, Brandon Cesmat, Shadab Zeest Hashimi, Tomas Gayton, Lyn Lifshi, Charles Entrekin and Kim Shuck, a San Francisco Poet Laureate Emerita, among many other poets. You can find out more about Poetic Matrix Press at its website at www.poeticmatrix.com.

Poetic Matrix Press @ PO Box 1051, Lake Isabella, CA 93240  Editor- John Peterson

 

Ways To Support This Project

*Pre-ordering before publication is a way to assist the Press and the publication.  The books will be mailed to you at no additional cost and as soon as  CLOUDBREAK is available. That will be most likely before it is up on on Amazon and Bookshop.org or available in bookstores, depending on when you donate. 

Publication is expected  May/June, 2021.

Please tell your friends! 

 

Options

1. For a contribution of $25 dollars the contributor will receive a copy of the book, CLOUDBREAK.

2.For a contribution of $30 dollars the contributor will receive a  personalized, signed copy of the book CLOUDBREAK

3.For a contribution of $ 50 dollars the contributor will receive a personalized, signed copy of the book CLOUDBREAK along with a personalized, signed copy of Heather’s debut book, INNER SUNSET, published in mid-summer, 2019 by Blue Light Press.

4. For a contribution of $75 dollars the contributor will receive a personalized, signed copy of the book, CLOUDBREAK, a personalized signed copy of Heather’s debut book, INNER SUNSET and an anthology of Poetic Matrix Poets; SO MANY VOICES.

5. For a contribution of $100 of general support to this project so Poetic Matrix Press can continue to publish poets like Heather, you can be a part of showing that Crowd Funding can be a viable way for poets and small presses to bring art and literature to the community. Be a backer at any level you wish.  You will receive TWO THANK-YOU NOTES OF GRATITUDE,  one from Poetic Matrix Press, John Peterson Editor and another from Heather Saunders Estes the author of this project.  Feel free to contribute any amount that works for you 

Goal

The goal is to reach a total of $2,500. The funding from this project will be applied only to publishing and distribution of this book. 

A cover is still being designed that will relate to the poems in  CLOUDBREAK. Heather will keep you posted on the progress and put a photo of the cover up on this site and Heather's website as soon as it is  finalized. 

 

Heather’s Writing.

Heather writes narrative and lyric poems and occasional flash fiction. She also seeks to improve her photography. The inspiration for her work comes from her memories of family and friends,  growing up in New England, living in San Francisco's Inner Sunset neighborhood, as well as her work with Planned Parenthood and other social justice issues. She has studied and consulted with Diane Frank, Ellen Bass, Kwame Dawes, Barry Goldensohn, Tom Centolella, Major Jackson, Vijay Seshadri, Peg Boyers, Brian Tierney, Peter Balakian and others. She appreciates her Poetry Group members for their ongoing support, critiques and friendship.  

You can check out her work at www.poeticmatrix.com after the book is published. Read  many of her poems anytime at her website and blog https://heathersaundersestes.com/ Follow her on Facebook for updates @  H.S.Estes.

 

Praise so far for CLOUDBREAK

Linda Williams, President and CEO, 416 Holdings writes:

As one of Heather’s former Planned Parenthood CEO colleagues, I’ve watched with wonder and delight as she has blossomed into an accomplished poet of depth and complexity. Her new book demonstrates a deep understanding and exploration of the tangled relationships between our memories and our myths. As she says, “Perhaps memory doesn’t matter to truth.” This is the first book of poetry I have ever read straight through at a single sitting. I couldn’t stop.

 

Praise for INNER SUNSET, Heather's 2019 Debut Book of Poetry

Barry Goldensohn, Author of The Hundred Yard Dash Man, followed by Snake in the Spine and Wolf in the Heart writes:

" This book is full of lyricism, animist and mystical often, about the natural world of ocean, trees, fog, birds, insects, and yet, surprisingly and vividly anchored in the city, the house, through windows, walks and wide open eyes. It reward reading and rereading. as its full context enriches and widens."

 

Robin Becker, Author of The Black Bear Inside Me writes:

"As natural historian, writing of contemporary life in San francisco, Estes appreciate the "seal heads of surfers," and the cedar waxwings in their "speed skater helmets." City-dweller, she also knows the public park and the highway barrier, where someone spray-painted the word "RESIST." Techno-savvy, she admits, I give my credit card to the waiter/knowing we have all been hacked." In her neighborhood -- "They tore down and trucked away the pieces/ of the little 1950 stucco house"--Estes confronts tumultuous transformations. I admire the wisdom in "What they do now can never be undone," even as the speaker finds comfort in "plover hieroglyphs."
 

 

Risks and Challenges;

The primary purpose for your contribution is to support Small Press publishers like Poetic Matrix Press and to be a part of the production of this book - CLOUDBREAK. Independent film producers have become the heart of the film industry; Small Press publishers have become the heart of the publishing world. They give voices to a vast number of writers. There is a  60 day goal of $2500, and your contributions are very appreciated. Poetry publishing is a labor of love and art.

story:
What the Book is About

My name wasn't on the Forbes 400 List of wealthiest Americans, but until the winter of 1983, I was living a fairly comfortable life. A Day at the Fare: One Woman's Welfare Journey is the story of my flight from a cozy, middle-class home in Savannah, Georgia and my plunge into a life on welfare while living in rough-and-tumble, low-income neighborhoods of Jacksonville, Florida.

The memoir describes how I ended up on public assistance, adapted to a grueling lifestyle as a lowly recipient and then rebounded from my loss of economic security.

                                             From a neighborhood lined with these...

                                                   ...to a neighborhood lined with these

Twenty-eight years old, with two children and an income that was well below poverty level, the most basic necessities became luxuries. I did what was necessary to survive in a crime-infested, drug-ridden community, while I struggled to create something better. I sought out and used every resource, kept the faith and jumped through one hoop after the other, but I never expected that "the system" I relied upon would be a source of so many of my problems.

Despite a plethora of obstacles, through education I discovered what might be a way for me to move beyond welfare. However, because of my household's economic frailty, I first had to ensure that conditions were right before I could free my family of its dependency.

General Patton defined success as how high someone bounces after hitting the bottom. A Day at the Fare: One Woman's Welfare Journey shows that the way to such victory is through courage, perseverance and self-discipline.

HERE'S A BRIEF SCENE FROM THE BOOK:

EXCERPT 1 

"I was doing a balancing act with three big, plastic garbage bags of dirty clothes filled to capacity wedged inside Cedric's red metal wagon and every bump along the sidewalks was challenging my balance. I pulled it with my back in a hunch as I herded the kids in the rain, just grateful for the change in my pocket. It had taken me half a dozen trips to the store, sometimes buying a single item, to collect the cash in change--the way I did for kerosene. Coin collecting from food stamp purchases was the only way I could pay for our laundry or buy soap, sanitary supplies, hair grease, toothpaste and other hygiene necessities I couldn't buy with food stamps. Diapers were more expensive than any of those items, so they were the toughest to save for, requiring more trips for change over a greater number of days.

Negotiating the curbs along Moncrief Road was difficult. Cedric and I had to hold down the bags inside the wagon while one of us held Devin's hand. Plodding along with the load jerking from side to side, I reminisced about my convenient laundry room in Savannah, when two of the garbage bags fell to the ground. We halted and I slung them back on top of the pile, and tried to mash them down. There was no rush, of course. We were already wet anyway.

We stood still again at the crosswalk of the 20th Street Expressway, where I noted how long it took the traffic lights to change and looked in both directions many times. It was hard to trust that every car in the double lanes of barreling traffic would come to a stop when those signals went from yellow to red. I strategized our positions for safety: Devin secured to my hip, Cedric pressing down on the mounds, and me tugging the wagon. Stepping off the curb and onto the freeway, I was a mother duck ensuring the safe passage of her ducklings. Out on the asphalt, entirely exposed to the openness of the roadway, the sidewalk on the other side might as well have been a mile away.

There would have been no sense in postponing the trip to the laundromat because of the chance of rain. A chance of rain is likely most days in Florida; it rained the day before and it was likely it would rain the next day, too. Meanwhile, the boys and I needed clean clothes. Thank you, food stamp change. And thank you, God, for the money and detergent to wash our clothes."

THANKS TO MY EARLY CONTRIBUTORS! I'LL POST ADDITIONAL EXCERPTS AS THE CAMPAIGN PROGRESSES: NEXT ONE WHEN IT REACHES $250 

About Me

I'm an empty-nester and former journalist who put off writing this memoir for over a decade while I worked full-time as a training instructor, raised my children, pursued higher education and managed a vibrant household.

Now I am eking out a living while happily materializing my vision: to apply my written and oral communications skills to benefit others in a more personal way. A big education buff, I consider literacy and a curiosity for learning important factors in minimizing poverty and welfare dependency. 

A former newspaper reporter and freelance journalist, I enjoy blogging. I have created Poverty and Welfare in the United States as a place to discuss problems of and solutions to poverty and low-income survival, the state of education, welfare reform, income disparities, economic opportunities and welfare alternatives. 

Clowning around on Red Nose Day in May before stepping out
to help generate awareness about child poverty. 

My Mission

Since the early '90s, I've been confessing the story of that destitute period of my past. Whether my listener is someone fortunate enough to have never needed public assistance or a person who is presently struggling, they lean forward and their eyes widen as I summarize my harrowing experiences. Many fumble for the words to respond and others remark, "I had no idea that..."

People often declare, that after hearing about what I managed to rise up out of, they are certain they can overcome a challenge they are facing. Nodding and smiling, they appear more determined to give whatever it is their best shot. And practically everybody I explain my bygone ordeal to says, "You need to write a book. A lot of people would benefit from hearing your story."

So I did.

With the manuscript completed and ready for the next stages of development, my mission is to make sure that A Day at the Fare's poignant messages inform and inspire as many readers as possible.

                            Documents I referenced while writing A Day at the Fare.

I bared my soul in this book in order to depict how:
  • the current societal stigma surrounding welfare is no different than that of decades ago
  • adversity can strike anyone at anytime
  • life is about choices, even more so when living in survival mode with low or no income
  • the keys to welfare independence include exercising resourcefulness and maintaining an "odds-beater" attitude
  • today's welfare system doesn't appear to have improved much from how it operated in the '80s
MY VISION IS to create and circulate a compelling, well-written, high-quality book available in paperback, eBook and audio formats and after publication, to speak publicly, educating and motivating audiences by expanding upon its topics. I also intend to connect with concerned organizations and determine what I can do to help reduce poverty through literacy, education and inspiration.

Why I Am Asking for Your Support

I thought I could do it all alone: write my book, self-publish it and market it. I was wrong; it's not that simple--or low cost. To make my manuscript the best it can be and launch the book into the marketplace and beyond, I need the expertise of others every step of the way. And expertise costs. The success of this campaign will determine how many people will benefit from A Day at the Fare's message of tenacity and resolve.

What Is the Impact of "A Day at the Fare?"

From talking to people in church groups and writers' groups, on planes and on the Internet, in libraries, coffee shops and college classrooms, I've heard how my story corrects some common misconceptions about welfare and rekindles a person's belief in the ability to conquer adversity by applying dogged determination.

By contributing to this campaign you will:
  • provide a source of inspiration for those who are undergoing a personal trial
  • become part of an initiative to address an overlooked aspect of impoverished peoples' needs: self-esteem and belief in themselves--two essentials for taking action to assume more responsibility for and control of their lives
  • help dispel the myths of what life on welfare in the United States is like. Many persons who sit in judgement of recipients have never experienced economic hardship or the frustration of dealing with the welfare system
  • support efforts to encourage welfare recipients that they, too, have what it takes to leave "the fare"
  • assist in stimulating an informed, speaking-from-experience dialogue about what works and what doesn't work in today's welfare system
  • enable me to fulfill a new, even more meaningful purpose in life

What I Need and What You Get

If this campaign reaches its funding goal of $11,000, here's how it will be spent:
  • Professional editing services for the manuscript: $1,500 - $1,800
  • Cover designs for print, eBook and audio book, plus additional artwork: $595
  • Text formatting and interior design for print and eBook - $500
  • ISBN registration: $125
  • Fulfillment of perks, including shipping costs: $1,900
  • Indiegogo's share: 5% ($500)
  • Spiral-bound copies of revised manuscript (includes postage both ways) for beta readers: $237
  • Proofreading service: $600
  • Professional studio recording time for audiobook: $1,500 - $1,700
  • Professional headshot photos: $175
  • Marketing and advertising startup: $2,000
  • PayPal and credit card fees: 3-5% ($800)

ESTIMATED TOTAL: $10,932

And here are the fantastic, one-of-a-kind "A Day at the Fare" perks that can be yours:
  • A most sincere thanks from me via e-mail
  • A meticulously scribed A Day at the Fare Thank-You note card sent by snail mail
  • A download of the eBook
  • A fastidiously signed copy of the print book
  • A carefully autographed copy of A Day at the Fare's awesome front cover artwork, suitable for framing. (You're gonna love it.)
  • A download of the audio book, as read by the author
  • Mentions of support on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google+
  • Your very own "A Day at the Fare" cover artwork mug
  • Your name listed on the book's Acknowledgements page
  • Mention of your support on my website's "Helps and Hurts" acknowledgement page 
  • A 30-minute Q&A session with me via Skype
  • A talk given by me to a group of your choice: within 300 miles of Hampton Roads, Virginia, anywhere via Skype or anywhere else in the U.S., if you provide airfare
  • 15 signed copies of the book for your group, 15 signed copies of the cover artwork suitable for framing and 5 USB drives loaded with the audiobook

If the funding goal is reached, A Day at the Fare: One Woman's Welfare Journey will be released this winter. The audio book will be available Spring 2016.

I've got stretch goals, too. Should this campaign supersede its funding objectives I will: 

  • Attend the upcoming conference "Beyond Housing: A National Conversation on Child Homelessness and Poverty 2016" hosted by the Institute for Children, Poverty and Homelessness (ICPH) in NYC January 13 -15
  • Volunteer to travel to and speak at an event for one of the non-profit organizations which assisted me during the time period described in the book
  • Expand my marketing efforts
  • Consider having a book launch party. That would be wonderful.
  • Purchase new eyeglasses. This pair has had it!

WATCH THE PROJECT UNFOLD RIGHT HERE!! I can't wait to share the excitement with you via regular updates.


    Risks and Challenges

    I CAN DO THIS! I've been writing for 30 years and have had hundreds of stories and articles published. As a single-parent mom, I have acquired some pretty amazing juggling skills that transition to this project perfectly. Having earned a MS in management, a MS in human resources management and a BA in communications is also helpful. And talking with people, conducting presentations and facilitating are second nature to me; I've spent 12 years in the classroom as a training instructor, I'm a Toastmaster and I'm motivated to touch people's lives.  

    Risks. If I do not achieve my funding goal and can't hire the help I need, completing A Day at the Fare will take much longer. Given the current wobbly status of low-to-middle income people in our country, doesn't the idea of further delaying the dissemination of my book's important messages sound absolutely awful?

    With adequate funding there is no risk of the project not reaching completion.

    But, if this campaign does not reach its funding goal, based upon how much money is generated, I will use it to achieve these high-priority tasks:

    1. Have the manuscript edited
    2. Cover designed and
    3. Text formatted for print and eBook
    4. Then go back to "the drawing board." I will not give up.

    There Are Also Other Ways You Can Help

    Maybe making a monetary donation isn't possible, but still you would like to help. That's easy. Please use the handy Indiegogo social media Share Tools (buttons) at the bottom of this page to spread the news about A Day at the Fare to your family, friends and colleagues.

    Either way, your involvement in the unfolding of this influential book is greatly appreciated. Thanks for taking the time to watch the video and read about my project.

    Best to You,

    Pamela 



    EXCERPTS AND UPDATES:

    Thanks to my latest contributors, I made it to the $150 milestone, so here's Excerpt 2 as promised. I'll post another when the campaign reaches $250, and then more as we work our way up to revealing a draft of the book's cover.  THANK YOU to the campaign's contributors for believing in and supporting my project!

    EXCERPT 2:

    "I began my tour, tiptoeing with caution, in case I wasn't alone. The front room was a casualty: huge cracks ran up two walls with chunks of plaster missing, a broken chandelier hung dangerously low from its wires and a heap of clothes and other things lay in the middle of the faded vinyl floor. In one bedroom, a section of the ceiling had caved in, and in the other one, the bottom half of a window had been covered with plywood. The kitchen was ghastly, especially the area where a stove used to sit: the vacant wall was coated with dark brown streams of grease that had stopped short as they oozed towards the floor.

    The house was an absolute mess. There was nothing I could do with it or for it. Beside the filth, collapse and decay, there was something else present: a vibration that I equated with death. It wasn't just the hollowness, its rankness or grunge that disturbed me, but its grim ambiance. Who knows what has gone on in here? The house was too near its own end to help me launch a new beginning.

    On my way out, I stopped to kick through the pile of stuff in the middle of the living room floor. A spread of newspapers fell aside and uncovered a white linen Christmas tablecloth with dozens of intricately embroidered poinsettias and a dainty lace trim. The two of us had something in common; we represented class in the midst of rubble. On a whim, I decided to rescue it and make it a part of my future revival. Together we crossed over the windowsill and back into the land of the living.

    The boys didn't get to go inside that house, either. When Cedric asked how it was, I just told him, "bad--real bad." As  I positioned my left hand on the steering wheel and was about to turn the key with my right, I smelled something. Ugh! The stench of the house was on my hands.

    The third address I'd written down, two bedrooms at $125 a month, was on McMillan Street. The house was another version of the same thing. The roof had a bumpy patchwork of different-colored shingles and strips of aluminum siding on the driveway side were hanging loose. The front gate was locked, but like many others who it seemed had visited the place, I simply clambered over a portion of chain link fence to get into the yard. I had barely opened the front door and set foot inside when an odor resembling raw sewage sent me running back out. I'd seen and smelled enough. This isn't gonna work.

    I'd spent the day running around town, and all I was doing was burning gas and adding miles to my rental truck bill. Not to mention that all I'd seen was shitholes. I didn't expect to find anything near the level of comfort I had left behind in Savannah--that would not have been realistic--but neither did I foresee being forced to live in such deplorable conditions. With that stark realization, I retreated to the truck wistful and light-headed."


    EXCERPT 3:

    "Friday night was like camping--without the warmth of a fire, since we still didn't  have power. Dinner was canned green beans, cold bologna sandwiches and fruit punch drink. While there was daylight, the children and I moved about like everyone else, but by nightfall we were huddled around the light of candles and using a flashlight to wander around. I had done my best, given the thorny circumstances leading to securing the apartment, but there was no way I could have timed the move to avoid suffering the temporary problems. Grateful that we weren't on the streets adding to the rental truck bill, I was at peace about them.

    We worn worn out, anyway. I embraced the sleep induced by the evening's early darkness--except for the overnight chill of temperatures fluctuating between the 40s and 50s. The cozy moving quilts were with Mr. Lawson. Devin and I slept nestled to one another, wrapped in bed sheets and our daily clothes, while Cedric lay on his own mattress. How will we warm ourselves come winter? A space heater downstairs isn't going to send heat upstairs. I'll have to figure something out about that.

    Since it had worked for us before, once again we walked to McDonald's to wash up in the ladies' room and wolf down a couple of toasty breakfast sandwiches. It was our first full day at home and there was plenty of work for me to do. There was sweeping to be done throughout the apartment, as well as unpacking boxes, setting the plants around and hand washing and air-drying what I could of our clothes. One of my main tasks was reassembling Devin's crib so he could at least have the familiarity of his own bed. How alien the fine white crib with the Winnie the Pooh Plexi-Glass end panel appeared in the drab room. The lackluster space was nothing like the cheerful, mint green bedroom he'd had in Savannah, with its tall windows, white baseboards with matching crown molding, marble fireplace and polished hardwood floors. The most noticeable feature of the boys' new room was its contrast to the other: a single, decaying window, nondescript baseboards painted the same bland color as the walls and a mottled, gray tile-square floor.

    Shutting out the memories of a house gone by, I returned to reality, putting a sheet on the mattress and pulling the crib away from the window to avoid Devin sleeping in a draft. Cedric's twin bed fit along the longer wall."

    EXCERPT 4:

    "My heart was racing. As we hurried back to the truck, I kissed the keys I held between my fingers. I felt liberated. All of the driving around was about to stop, and at long last the truck could be unloaded. Explaining to the children that we probably had a place, I was practically shouting. Granted, I hadn't even seen it, but I had pretty much concluded that I was going to take it. What position am I in to say no? This was our sixth day with the truck and I was as close as I could be to renting anything just so I could unload it. 

    Driving nearer to the address, and compared to the other places I'd seen, I decided the area wasn't looking that bad. I turned onto Payne Avenue and drove up to an enormous, pink U-shaped cluster of concrete tenements taking up the entire lengthy block. I turned right onto West 12th Street and scanned the address numbers until I found mine: 6120, close to the road's dead end. I walked up to the door, inserted my prized key and, with breath held, pushed it open.

    A single multi-paned window lit the tiny front room. The walls were beige, and freshly painted; I could still smell it in the air. The dull brown tile floor had been patched over. There were indentations in it where previous tenants planted space heaters, and at the top of the wall I could see the thing he'd called the "flue." Built into the same wall was a closet under the steps, its door cut at the angle of the staircase leading to the second floor.

    The kitchen was trying to be white, though it was too old, to succeed. It too, contained only one window--a slim one, that was a crank case type, like the one in the front room. The cabinets were so thickly layered with coats of paint that the hinges had a tough time swinging. I looked under the sink. Flakes of rust from the bottom of the crusted cabinet drawers had fallen to the space below, and there were gaping holes in the wall around the pipes. Outside the small kitchen window I saw a large, open common yard, lined with individual pole sets for clotheslines. I hadn't noticed as I'd driven up, but the building was adjacent to railroad tracks.

    I next climbed the green pebbly stairs to have a look at the bedrooms. The front one, the one I decided would be mine, was a grayish, pale blue. The back one had been painted a drab schoolhouse green. Each had one multi-paned window. Neither closet had a door. I would have to hang curtains there.

    The little  bathroom was shadowy. The tub, barely trimmed in dried-out caulk, had tarnished, old-fashioned faucets and a stationary showerhead. I slid my hand across its irregular surface. Certain spots were gritty, while others were covered with paint. But at least it was a standard-size tub. Atop the outdated sink were separate mismatched hot and cold-water spigots and the toilet boasted a black horseshoe-shaped seat, the kind I remembered from elementary school. I couldn't test the plumbing, because the water wasn't on.

    Living in cement would take some adjusting; it would be like residing inside a vault. And the unit was awfully small; not one room in my home in Savannah had been as small as any of those in the apartment--except maybe the closet in the master bedroom. But although I was torn between relief and dismay, I believed that I could make the apartment do.

    I took the boys inside and let them walk through. It was about to be a done deal; the frantic search for housing was over. I would finally have a home base to begin rebuilding my life from. What a relief!"

What the Book is About 
My name wasn't on the Forbes 400 List of wealthiest Americans, but until the winter of 1983, I was living a fairly comfortable life. A Day at the Fare: One Woman's Welfare Journey is the story of my flight from a cozy, middle-class home in Savannah, Georgia and my plunge into a life on welfare while living in rough-and-tumble, low-income neighborhoods of Jacksonville, Florida.
The memoir describes how I ended up on public assistance, adapted to a grueling lifestyle 
as a lowly recipient and then rebounded from my loss of economic 
security.

                                             From a neighborhood lined with these...
                                                   ...to a neighborhood lined with these

Twenty-eight years old, with two children and an income that was well below poverty level, the most basic necessities became luxuries. I did what was necessary to survive in a crime-infested, drug-ridden community, while I struggled to create something better. I sought out and used every resource, kept the faith and jumped through one hoop after the other, but I never expected that "the system" I relied upon would be a source of so many of my problems.

Despite a plethora of obstacles, through education I discovered what might be a way for me to move beyond welfare. However, because of my 
household's economic frailty, I first had to ensure that conditions were right before I could free my family of its dependency.
General Patton defined success as how high someone bounces after hitting the bottom. A Day at the Fare: One Woman's Welfare Journey shows that the way to such victory is through courage, perseverance and self-discipline.
HERE'S A BRIEF SCENE FROM THE BOOK:
EXCERPT 1  

"I was doing a balancing act with three big, plastic garbage bags of dirty clothes filled to capacity wedged inside Cedric's red metal wagon and every bump along the sidewalks was challenging my balance. I pulled it with my back in a hunch as I herded the kids in the rain, just grateful for the change in my pocket. It had taken me half a dozen trips to the store, sometimes buying a single item, to collect the cash in change--the way I did for kerosene. Coin collecting from food stamp purchases was the only way I could pay for our laundry or buy soap, sanitary supplies, hair grease, toothpaste and other hygiene necessities I couldn't buy with food stamps. Diapers were more expensive than any of those items, so they were the toughest to save for, requiring more trips for change over a greater number of days.
Negotiating the curbs along Moncrief Road was difficult. Cedric and I had to hold down the bags inside the wagon while one of us held Devin's hand. Plodding along with the load jerking from side to side, I reminisced about my convenient laundry room in Savannah, when two of the garbage bags fell to the ground. We halted and I slung them back on top of the pile, and tried to mash them down. There was no rush, of course. We were already wet anyway.
We stood still again at the crosswalk of the 20th Street Expressway, where I noted how long it took the traffic lights to change and looked in both directions many times. It was hard to trust that every car in the double lanes of barreling traffic would come to a stop when those signals went from yellow to red. I strategized our positions for safety: Devin secured to my hip, Cedric pressing down on the mounds, and me tugging the wagon. Stepping off the curb and onto the freeway, I was a mother duck ensuring the safe passage of her ducklings. Out on the asphalt, entirely exposed to the openness of the roadway, the sidewalk on the other side might as well have been a mile away. 
There would have been no sense in postponing the trip to the laundromat because of the chance of rain. A chance of rain is likely most days in Florida; it rained the day before and it was likely it would rain the next day, too. Meanwhile, the boys and I needed clean clothes. Thank you, food stamp change. And thank you, God, for the money and detergent to wash our clothes."

About Me
I'm an empty-nester and former journalist who put off writing this memoir for over a decade while I worked full-time as a training instructor, raised my children, pursued higher education and managed a vibrant household. 
Now I am eking out a living while happily materializing my vision: to apply my written and oral communications skills to benefit others in a more personal way. A big education buff, I consider literacy and a curiosity for learning important factors in minimizing poverty and welfare dependency.  

A former newspaper reporter and freelance journalist, I enjoy blogging. I have created Poverty and Welfare in the United States as a place to discuss problems of and solutions to poverty and
low-income survival, the state of education, welfare reform, income disparities,
economic opportunities and welfare alternatives.  


Clowning around on Red Nose Day in May before stepping out to help generate awareness about child poverty. 

My Mission 

Since the early '90s, I've been confessing the story of that destitute period of my past. Whether my listener is someone fortunate enough to have never needed public assistance or a person who is presently struggling, they lean forward and their eyes widen as I summarize my harrowing experiences. Many fumble for the words to respond and others remark, "I had no idea that..." 
People often declare, that after hearing about what I managed to rise up out of, they are certain they can overcome a challenge they are facing. Nodding and smiling, they appear more determined to give whatever it is their best shot. And practically everybody I explain my bygone ordeal to says, "You need to write a 
book. A lot of people would benefit from hearing your story." 
So I did. 

With the manuscript completed and ready for the next stages of development, my mission is to make sure that A Day at the Fare's poignant messages inform and inspire as many readers as possible. 
                           
Documents I referenced while writing A Day at the Fare.I bared my soul in this book in order to depict how:

the current societal stigma surrounding welfare is no different than that of decades ago
adversity can strike anyone at anytime
life is about choices, even more so when living in survival mode with low or no income

the keys to welfare independence include exercising resourcefulness and maintaining an "odds-beater" attitude 

today's welfare system doesn't appear to have improved much from how it operated in the '80s
 MY VISION IS to create and circulate a compelling, well-written, high-quality book available in paperback, eBook and audio formats and after publication, to speak publicly, educating and motivating audiences by expanding upon its topics. I also intend to connect with concerned organizations and determine what I can do to help reduce poverty through literacy, education and inspiration. 
Why I Am Asking for Your Support
I thought I could do it all alone: write my book, self-publish it and market it. I was wrong; it's not that simple--or low cost. To make my manuscript the best it can be and launch the book into the marketplace and beyond, I need the expertise of others every step of the way. And expertise costs. The success of this campaign will determine how many people will benefit from A Day at the Fare's message of tenacity and resolve.
What Is the Impact of "A Day at the Fare?"

From talking to people in church groups and writers' groups, on planes and on 
the Internet, in libraries, coffee shops and college classrooms, I've heard how my story corrects some common misconceptions about welfare and rekindles a person's belief in the ability to conquer adversity by applying dogged determination.
By contributing to this campaign you will:
provide a source of inspiration for those who are undergoing a personal trial
become part of an initiative to address an overlooked aspect of 
impoverished peoples' needs: self-esteem and belief in themselves--two essentials for taking action to assume more responsibility for and control of their lives
help dispel the myths of what life on welfare in the United States is like. Many persons who sit in judgement of recipients have never experienced economic hardship or the frustration of dealing with the welfare system

support efforts to encourage welfare recipients that they, too, have what it takes to leave "the fare"
assist in stimulating an informed, speaking-from-experience dialogue 
about what works and what doesn't work in today's welfare system
enable me to fulfill a new, even more meaningful purpose in life


  What I Need and What You GetIf this campaign reaches its funding goal of $11,000, here's how it will be spent: 
Professional editing services for the manuscript: $1,500 - $1,800
Cover designs for print, eBook and audio book, plus additional artwork: $595
Text formatting and interior design for print and eBook - $500
ISBN registration: $125

Fulfillment of perks, including shipping costs: $1,900
Indiegogo's share: 5% ($500)

Spiral-bound copies of revised manuscript (includes postage both ways) for beta readers: $237
Proofreading service: $600

Professional studio recording time for audiobook: $1,500 - $1,700

Professional headshot photos: $175
Marketing and advertising startup: $2,000
PayPal and credit card fees: 3-5% ($800)

ESTIMATED TOTAL: $10,932 And here are the fantastic, one-of-a-kind "A Day at the Fare" perks that can be yours: 
A most sincere thanks from me via e-mail 

A meticulously scribed A Day at the Fare Thank-You note card sent by snail mail
A download of the eBook
A fastidiously signed copy of the print book

A carefully autographed copy of A Day at the Fare's awesome front cover artwork, suitable for framing. (You're gonna love it.) 

A download of the audio book, as read by the author

Mentions of support on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google+
Your very own "A Day at the Fare" cover artwork mug

Your name listed on the book's Acknowledgements page
Mention of your support on my website's "Helps and Hurts" acknowledgement page  

A 30-minute Q&A session with me via Skype

A talk given by me to a group of your choice: within 300 miles 
of Hampton Roads, Virginia, anywhere via Skype or anywhere else in the 
U.S., if you provide airfare
15 signed copies of the book for your group, 15 signed copies of the cover artwork suitable for framing and 5 USB drives loaded with the audiobook

If the funding goal is reached, A Day at the Fare: One Woman's Welfare Journey will be released this winter. The audio book will be available Spring 2016. I've got stretch goals, too. Should this campaign supersede its funding objectives I will:  
Attend the upcoming conference "Beyond Housing: A National Conversation on Child Homelessness and Poverty 2016" hosted by the Institute for Children, Poverty and Homelessness (ICPH) in NYC January 13 -15
Volunteer to travel to and speak at an event for one of the non-profit organizations which assisted me during the time period described in the book

Expand my marketing efforts
Consider having a book launch party. That would be wonderful.

Purchase new eyeglasses. This pair has had it! 


WATCH THE PROJECT UNFOLD RIGHT HERE!! I can't wait to share the excitement with you via regular updates.

    Risks and Challenges  I CAN DO THIS! I've been writing for 30 years and have had hundreds of stories and 
articles published. As a single-parent mom, I have acquired some pretty amazing juggling skills that transition to this project perfectly. Having earned a MS in management, a 
MS in human resources management and a BA in communications is also helpful. And talking with people, conducting presentations and facilitating are second nature to me; I've spent 12 years in the classroom as a training instructor, I'm a Toastmaster and I'm motivated to touch people's lives.   
Risks. If I do not achieve my funding goal and can't hire the help I need, completing A Day at the Fare will take much longer. Given the current wobbly status of low-to-middle income people in our country,
 doesn't the idea of further delaying the dissemination of my book's important messages sound absolutely awful?

With adequate funding there is no risk of the project not reaching completion.

But, if this campaign does not reach its funding goal, based upon how much money is generated, I will use it to achieve these high-priority tasks:

Have the manuscript edited 
Cover designed and

Text formatted for print and eBook

Then go back to "the drawing board." I will not give up.


  There Are Also Other Ways You Can Help
 Maybe making a monetary donation isn't possible, but still you would like to help. That's easy. Please use the handy Indiegogo social media Share Tools (buttons) at the bottom of this page to spread the news about A Day at the Fare to your family, friends and colleagues. 
Either way, your involvement in the unfolding of this influential book is greatly appreciated. Thanks for taking the time to watch the video and read about my project.

Best to You, 
Pamela

Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.
